description: LOS ANGELES  Even with millions of Latinos becoming newly eligible to vote every election cycle, many fail to cast ballots. Whether Latinos will turn out in large numbers this midterm election  this time with party control in Washington at stake  remains a big question.

title: Name One Really Famous Baseball Player. Well Wait.
description: Major League Baseball has a dream matchup for the World Series as two of its marquee franchises, the Boston Red Sox and the Los Angeles Dodgers, face off.

title: Mamaroneck Village, N.Y.: A Low-Key Vibe on the Long Island Sound
description: It was on a Thursday that Jonathan and Ariel Treiber first saw the listing for the house in the village of Mamaroneck and fell in love. On Friday, they toured the property and made an offer. Over the weekend, knowing the market was competitive, they increased their bid twice. By Monday afternoon, despite 11 rival offers, the house was theirs.

title: The Problem With Fixing WhatsApp? Human Nature Might Get in the Way
description: Should the world worry about WhatsApp? Has it become a virulent new force in global misinformation and political trickery?

title: Paradise Threatened: Fijis War Against Climate Change
description: Between the international airport in Nadi, Fiji, and the capital city of Suva, the coastal road on the island of Viti Levu is lined with resorts and clogged with tour buses. Its a route I took several times this spring when I visited friends in Suva, a bustling port city where cruise ships drop anchor year-round and deposit thousands of tourists.

title: Cuomo-Molinaro Debate: 5 Takeaways
description: It finally happened: After days of back-and-forth over who was too afraid to face whom, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his Republican challenger, Marcus J. Molinaro, squared off on Tuesday in their first and likely only debate.

title: The Doctor Zhivago Nobel Dust-up
description: The drumbeats started on Nov. 21, 1957, when the paper noted that Boris Pasternaks epic novel, Dr. Zhivago, was about to hit stores in Italy over the protests of the Soviet government. The Soviets, who had allowed Pasternak to approach foreign publishers in a short-lived show of benevolence, quickly regretted their decision and tried to force the books Italian publisher into returning the manuscript for revisions. They demurred.

title: Explosive Devices, Sandra Day OConnor, World Series: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Migrant Caravan and the Midterms
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: New York Today: An Uncomfortable Debate
description: Good morning on this chilly Wednesday.

title: #IAmSexist
description: Men, listen up.

title: Jamal Khashoggi and the Competing Visions of Islam
description: Jamal Khashoggis murder by Saudi agents in Istanbul doesnt just cast a harsh light on the authoritarian and reckless behavior of Prince Mohamad bin Salman of Saudi Arabia; it also highlights the rivalry between Turkey and Saudi Arabia, which represent competing forms of Islam.

title: Call It the Bullpen World Series
description: BOSTON  Dig back more than a century in the World Series archives, and the line scores look familiar and reassuring.

title: DealBook Briefing: Whipsawing Markets Rattle Investors
description: Good Wednesday. Want this by email? Sign up here.

title: Did Trumps Attacks Hurt Harley-Davidsons Sales? Its Saying Little
description: The DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines  and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

title: In The Fog, Made After Halloween, Seafaring Zombies Arrive
description: Halloween (1978), the quintessential slasher film, made John Carpenter famous. His follow-up, The Fog (1980), sought to put some narrative meat on the genres bones.

title: The Coming of Age of Transgender Literature
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.  The Pioneer Valley in western Massachusetts is a cradle of social progress  a place where L.G.B.T.Q. is often followed by I.A. (for intersex and asexual), theres a Stonewall Center (now 33 years old), and gender-nonconforming parents have a nickname of choice (its Baba).

title: Zero Tolerance Immigration Policy Surprised Agencies, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration did not tell key government agencies about its zero tolerance immigration policy before publicly announcing it in April, leaving the officials responsible for carrying it out unprepared to handle the resulting separations of thousands of children from their families, according to a government report released on Wednesday.

title: Rome Escalator Collapse Injures Dozens in Subway Station
description: ROME  The authorities in Italy on Wednesday were investigating why a subway escalator in Rome suddenly sped up during rush hour and raced to the bottom, dumping riders in a crush of bodies and leaving dozens hurt, including one man with a seriously injured foot.

title: What You Get for $600,000
description: A timber-framed house in East Hampton, Conn.; a 19th-century log cabin in Winchester, Va.; and a midcentury-modern home in Grand Junction, Colo.

title: Former Surgeons General Recount Political Pressure on the Job
description: It made an arresting tableau: four former surgeons general, aged 68 to 85, all in their blue admirals uniforms, together on stage like four grizzled Civil War veterans rehashing their biggest battles, and how they were treated afterward by the President and Congress.

title: $600,000 Homes in Connecticut, Virginia and Colorado
description: This timber-framed house is in the Connecticut River community of Middle Haddam, in the town of East Hampton. It was built with a high-end prefabricated panel system. It is about half an hour from Hartford and Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: Bostons Other Baseball Treasure
description: BOSTON  Tobacco juice and sunflower seeds are no longer strewn along the right-field line, and the trolley tracks that guided legions of fans directly into Braves Field have long since been paved over.

title: Bodyguard Was a Sensation in Britain. But Can It Conquer America?
description: LONDON  Its been pretty grim in Britain over the last few months. Brexit, Brexit, Brexit. Newspaper headlines and social media keep telling us that the country has never been more divided. Brexit preppers are stockpiling food and medication. Half the cabinet is in a perennial state of officially outraged fury and imminent resignation. The beleaguered prime minister, Theresa May, keeps insisting there is a way forward.

title: Do Not Double-Major
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: California Today: Dodgers Pursuing Their First Championship Since 1988
description: Good morning.

title: Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and CNN Offices Are Sent Pipe Bombs
description: [Read the latest on the pipe bombs sent to the actor Robert De Niro and the former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.]

title: A Birds-Eye View of the Bahamas
description: This property on the coast of Nassau, which has a two-story home and a private lighthouse, is on the market for $3.5 million.

title: House Hunting in  the Bahamas
description: Solomons Lighthouse, a waterfront estate on the northeast shore of Nassau, in the Bahamas, takes its name from the private lighthouse on the property that offers panoramic views of Montagu Bay, the island of New Providence and the Atlantic Ocean. The estate also includes a 7,000-square-foot British Colonial-style house, a swimming pool and a recently renovated backyard area.

title: A Rejuvenated Blake Griffin Scores 50 Points in Pistons Win
description: Blake Griffin came tearing into the N.B.A. in 2010 after being the No. 1 overall draft pick in 2009 for the Clippers, earning five consecutive All-Star selections. In later years, he continued to score around 20 points a game, but began to be hampered by injuries, and the Clippers finally traded him to the Pistons last January. His days as an elite player seemed to be over.

title: German Artists Who Blazed a Path Cut Short by War
description: Its hard not to leave Franz Marc and August Macke: 1909-1914, an alternately thrilling and dizzying exhibition on the artistic friendship of two important German painters, saddened by the tragic end of both mens careers.

title: Kerry Washington Has Something to Fear
description: Kerry Washington shifted a bit on the cozy couch we were sharing in her dressing room at the Booth Theater, her eyes trained inquisitively on mine.

title: Spinal Cord Repaired in the Womb, in First Surgery of its Kind in U.K.
description: LONDON  A team of surgeons has repaired the spinal cords of two babies while they were still in their mothers wombs, the first surgery of its kind in Britain.

title: Private Equitys Broadband Rush Is Riskier Than It Looks
description: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines  and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Good morning. Steven Raichlen gave us a great story from Monroe County, Ky., this week, all about the pork-shoulder steaks they cook there over hickory embers, and dip in hot-pepper sauce. Its barbecue thats not really barbecue, and of course we have a recipe (above) that you can try out this weekend if youre game. (We also got a good one for pickled eggs, using roughly the same sauce.) A grilled pork-shoulder steak dipped in hot-pepper sauce is one of lifes great pleasures. (Pickled eggs, same deal.)

title: Goods Mart: A 7-Eleven for All You Organic People
description: Youve heard of conscious uncoupling. But a conscious convenience store?

title: The Pope Doesnt Understand China
description: HONG KONG  Last month the Vatican announced that it had come to a provisional agreement with the government of China over the appointment of Catholic bishops. Supporters of the deal say that it finally brings unity after longstanding division  between an underground Church loyal to the pope and an official church approved by the Chinese authorities  and that with it, the Chinese government has for the first time recognized the authority of the pope. In fact, the deal is a major step toward the annihilation of the real Church in China.

title: XXXTentacion Discusses Abuse and Stabbings on Tape Released by Prosecutors
description: Before the popular rapper and singer XXXTentacion was shot and killed in Florida this summer, the 20-year-old musician had been on an accelerated track to mainstream success, with hit songs and albums that earned him a $10 million record deal for his next release.

title: Cold, Windy, Gray Day? Heart Attack Risk Is High
description: When the weather is bad, more people have heart attacks, Swedish researchers have found.

title: Theres a Black Man in the Childrens Area and Other Baseless Accusations
description: In To the Next BBQ Becky: Dont Call 911. Call 1-844-WYT-FEAR, Niecy Nash, the actress and comedian, uses a satirical infomercial to call attention to societys fear of the other, specifically when white people call the police on black people who are just going about their business.

title: For Two Architects, the Art They Own Is Entwined With Their Lives
description: Hilary Sample and Michael Meredith, a married couple and the founders of MOS Architects, dont think of the art on their walls as a collection, per se.

title: How to Make Friends
description: Welcome to The Edit. Each week in our newsletter, youll hear from college students and recent graduates about issues going on in their lives. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

title: Riverbanks Cultural Center Renamed After $1 Million Gift
description: Robert F. Smith initially preferred to keep this quiet. About a year ago, the businessman and philanthropist  who is chairman of Carnegie Hall and the largest donor to the Smithsonians National Museum of African American History and Culture  donated $1 million to the Cultural Performance Center at the Denny Farrell Riverbank State Park in Harlem.

title: Alexander Soros: The Hate That Is Consuming Us
description: On Monday afternoon an explosive device was delivered to my fathers home north of New York City. An alert member of our staff recognized the threat and called the police. Fortunately, the authorities were able to detonate the device safely. On Wednesday, the Secret Service said it had intercepted similar devices sent to the offices of former President Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

title: Even for Trump, There Is Such a Thing as Too Far
description: Over the past few weeks, on the campaign trail and at home in the White House, President Trump has made it clear that attacking immigrants is the main thrust of his midterm message. In 2016, his anti-immigrant campaign resonated with his core supporters and it may well again in 2018, but this year more people have been turned off by the reality of his anti-immigrant politics. As a result, Mr. Trumps vile strategy is more likely to backfire this time.

title: Saudi Crown Prince Calls Khashoggis Death Heinous
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The crown prince of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday denounced the heinous crime committed against Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident writer killed in Turkey. It was his most public attempt yet to separate himself from Saudi operatives suspected of the killing, who include some of the crown princes own aides.

title: Brazil Prepares to Elect a Hypocrite
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  For a liberal woman like me, its hard to understand why anyone would vote for a presidential candidate who has been described by international publications as racist, homophobic and sexist (Libration), a threat to democracy (The Economist), a Trump of the tropics (The Guardian), a xenophobe (Clarn) and a sympathizer with military dictatorships and torturers who has openly expressed fascist ideas (Zeit).

title: F.B.I. Arrests White Nationalist Leader Who Fled the Country for Central America
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. arrested the leader of a violent California neo-Nazi gang on a federal conspiracy charge after he fled the country earlier this month.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through Nov. 3. Tilton Gallery, 8 East 76th Street, Manhattan; 212-737-221, jacktiltongallery.com.

title: Review: Hilary Hahn Plays an Unabashedly Romantic Bach
description: Encores have never been an afterthought for Hilary Hahn. In recent years, this brilliant violinist has commissioned 27 short solo pieces from as many composers to expand her stash of end-of-concert treats.

title: Outrage Over a Handshake Between Khashoggi Son and the Crown Prince
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The image of the Saudi crown prince shaking the hand of a son of the slain journalist Jamal Khashoggi stoked outrage on social media on Wednesday as suspicions continue that the crown prince had a role in the killing.

title: In the Studio With Farshad Farzankia
description: The Copenhagen-based artist, who was born in Tehran, makes bright figurative canvases that explore otherness and cultural identity.

title: The Artist Who Is Selling Out Shows Just Two Years After He Started Painting
description: At just past 10 on a late summer morning, the artist Farshad Farzankia is sitting at a desk in his sun-seeped studio on the outskirts of Copenhagen, wearing paint-splattered Vans and old track pants, like a 90s skater kid now fully grown. Nursing a can of Coke and occasionally puffing on a hand-rolled cigarette, he doodles on a sheet of printer paper. Stacked against the walls are the large hypersaturated canvases that consume his days (and often nights, hence the early soda fix).

title: Review: Deutschland 86, an East-West Thriller, Looks South
description: You may find the scheme at the center of Deutschland 86 a bit confusing. Thats all right; so does Martin Rauch (Jonas Nay), the reluctant East German spy roped into carrying it out.

title: Dean Skelos, Ex-New York Senate Leader, Gets 4 Years and 3 Months in Prison
description: Dean G. Skelos, the former New York State Senate majority leader who wielded sweeping power in the Legislature for nearly a decade, was sentenced to four years and three months in prison on Wednesday for a corruption scheme involving his son.

title: In Two New Books, Unhappy Conservatives Ask: What Now?
description: To hear Max Boot tell it, he feels as forlorn as the despondent, battered elephant on the cover of his new book, The Corrosion of Conservatism: Why I Left the Right. Boot minutely describes a disillusionment that wasnt only painful and prolonged but existential. Here he is  a lifelong Republican with sterling neoconservative credentials (an enthusiastic supporter of the Iraq War and a champion of American empire)  explaining why hes eager for the day when the G.O.P. as currently constituted is burned to the ground.

title: 6 Attention-Getting Off Broadway Shows Are Back for Encores
description: Three weeks and done is often the run for an Off Broadway play. Every now and then, though, intrepid producers  following the lead of enthusiastic audiences  bring shows back for second editions, often longer and sometimes in spiffier theaters. Here are six shows, now playing or soon to reopen, that New York Times critics enjoyed the first time around. Dont count on a third chance.

title: A Changing Tennessee Weighs a Moderate or Conservative for Senate
description: MEMPHIS  As Phil Bredesen, the former Democratic governor of Tennessee now running for Senate, was wrapping up a voter forum at Rhodes College recently, the liberal-leaning mix of students, faculty and local residents began to grow restless from his unapologetically moderate brand of politics.

title: Midterm Election Poll: New Yorks 27th District, Collins vs. McMurray
description: This race wasnt supposed to be close; President Trump won the district by 25 points. But in August, Mr. Collins was charged with insider trading (he has maintained his innocence), and a recent poll showed him ahead by just three points.

title: Two Forms in Conversation
description: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

title: Midterm Election Poll: Utahs 4th District, Love vs. McAdams
description: The district is a boot-shaped expanse extending south from Salt Lake City, as a recent New York Tiimes article put it. Only 15 percent of the voters are registered Democrats, but the party won the seat narrowly in 2012.

title: Charlestons Tempting Treasures
description: A bustling downtown around King Street offers places to look and spend.

title: Behind the Cover: Candy Around the World
The Wildebeest Is One Highly Toned Machine
description: This time of year, the temperature routinely reaches 104 degrees in northern Botswana. The grasses recede, forcing herds of wildebeest to walk farther and farther from their only water source to graze. Humidity falls to about 10 to 15 percent.

title: The Battle for Congress Is Close. Heres the State of the Race.
description: The math currently favors the Democrats in the House and the Republicans in the Senate.

title: New York Sues Exxon Mobil, Saying It Deceived Shareholders on Climate Change
description: New Yorks attorney general sued Exxon Mobil on Wednesday, claiming the company defrauded shareholders by downplaying the expected risks of climate change to its business.

title: We Answer Your Internetting Questions About Drag Queens and Cat Pranks
description: Season 2 of Internetting has come to an end. On the final leg of our dystopian internet tour, babies failed, celebs were subdued, drag queens were commodified and girlfriends were terrorized via marriage proposal. And yet, we still have more questions than answers.

title: Tony Hoagland, Poet With a Wry Outlook, Is Dead at 64
description: Tony Hoagland, a widely admired poet who could be both humorous and heartfelt, often in the same poem, died on Tuesday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 64.

title: Adam Sandlers Netflix Special: His Most Satisfying Comedy in Years
description: In the middle of his easygoing hang of a new special, 100% Fresh, Adam Sandler, one of the biggest movie stars in the world, walks into a Times Square subway station and, disguised in a hoodie and sunglasses, tries his hand at busking.

title: Ross From Friends Didnt Do It: Your Wednesday Pop Culture Cheat Sheet
description: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

title: Just Embed a Phone Into This Editors Mind, Already
description: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Choire Sicha, the editor of the Styles desk at The Times, which reports on everything from weddings and fashion to social change and self-care, discussed the tech hes using.

title: Craving Some Americana? The Saturday Evening Post Archive Is Online
description: Nearly 200 years after its inception, The Saturday Evening Post has unveiled a new website with a digital archive of its issues dating back to 1821, as well as a gallery of its signature covers.

title: Review: Suspiria Is a Gaudy Freakout of Female Violence
description: Smeared in red and wrapped in woo-woo mystery, Suspiria is a fable of demonic possession. In storybook terms, its bad, bad trouble involves a young, outwardly nave American dancer, Susie (Dakota Johnson), whose tenure at an all-female school in Germany turns progressively strange. The other less interesting possession involves the Italian director Luca Guadagnino, who has taken a 1970s freakout from Dario Argento and turned it into a bloated fantasy of violently consuming female power. Its the old vagina dentata scare show, this time fancied up with art-house pretensions.

title: Donald Trumps Gay Amnesia
description: This article is part of the Frank Bruni newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the free newsletter every Wednesday.

title: Fracking Returns to Britain, and So Do Seismic Tremors Near Drilling Site
description: Less than two weeks after an energy company won a court battle over opponents who feared hydraulic fracturing would cause seismic tremors in northwest England, the drilling work appears to be doing just that.

title: Danny Leiner, Director Known for Stoner Films, Is Dead at 57
description: Danny Leiner, a director who turned the wanderings of the wasted into two successful movies, Dude, Wheres My Car? and Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle, died on Oct. 18 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 57.

title: In Sydney, a Feud Over Night Life Intensifies
description: [Sign up for the Australia Letter to get conversation starters and news with global context in your inbox each week.]

title: Racist Rant on Ryanair Flight Prompts Investigation by British Police
description: The British police say they are investigating a white man who berated a black woman with racist comments on a Ryanair plane last week, adding that they plan to turn over their findings to the Spanish authorities.

title: Alexandra Pelosi Plunges Into Trump Country
description: Alexandra Pelosis schedule over a recent 24 hours read like a liberal elite Mad Lib.

title: NBC Assigns Veteran Producer to Take Over Jimmy Fallons Tonight Show
description: At a crucial moment in late-night television, a new showrunner is taking over The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, a onetime ratings winner that lost its lead in total viewers soon after the inauguration of President Trump.

title: Fashion or Costume? You Decide
description: Halloween is the one night a year when you can step out in your most outlandish gear without feeling ridiculous. But for many in the fashion flock, such dressing up is a year-round event. Indeed, its getting harder to distinguish between the makings of a Halloween costume and the accessory of the moment.

title: CNN Found a Bomb at Its New York Office. Confusion and False Alarms Followed.
description: [Read the latest on the pipe bombs sent to the actor Robert De Niro and the former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.]

title: Rodrigo Rato, Ex-Chief of Spains Bankia, Loses Bid to Avoid Prison
description: MADRID  Rodrigo Rato, a former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was set to enter a Spanish prison on Thursday after failing to win an appeal of his 2017 conviction for credit card fraud while running Bankia, a giant Spanish lender that nearly collapsed  in 2012.

title: Annapurna Devi, Acclaimed but Reclusive Indian Musician, Dies at 91
description: Annapurna Devi, a noted Indian musician and teacher whose decision to stop performing relatively early in her career made her something of an enigma, died on Oct. 13 in Mumbai. She was 91.

title: After Bomb Scares, Trump Tries Bipartisanship, Then Blames the Media
description: MOSINEE, Wis.  A day after a national call for unity in the wake of the bomb scares targeting several prominent Democrats, President Trump blamed the Mainstream Media and Fake News for the anger and division thriving in the United States.

title: Still Clubbing at 82
description: Who says night life is only for the young?

title: Subway Fare That Stinks: Nachos, Meat ... Crab Legs?
description: It is an unspoken compact among subway riders in New York City: If you are going to eat on the train, keep it simple. But sometimes, there are messy scofflaws.

title: Getting Tough Over a Missile Pact Could Weaken America
description: Donald Trump is not the first American president to accuse Russia of violating the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty. President Barack Obama did so four years ago.

title: Scientists Push for a Crash Program to Scrub Carbon From the Air
description: WASHINGTON With time running out to avoid dangerous global warming, the nations leading scientific body on Wednesday urged the federal government to begin a research program focused on developing technologies that can remove vast quantities of carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere in order to help slow climate change.

title: Neglecting New Moms Health and Asians Mental Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Decembers Book Club Pick: Casey Geralds memoir, There Will Be No Miracles Here
description: THERE WILL BE NO MIRACLES HEREA MemoirBy Casey Gerald386 pp. Riverhead Books. $27.

title: Who Needs a Border Wall When You Have DS-5535?
description: On May 16, I accompanied my fiance to the United States Consulate in Casablanca, Morocco, for her visa interview. We had waited eight months for the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services to approve our application and the National Visa Center to issue an appointment. I booked her a return flight, hopeful that we would be flying back together to continue our lives in New York.

title: If I Win My District, Ill Get Rid of It
description: I am working hard to win the race for the 101st Assembly District in New York  and if I succeed, I will work just as hard to get rid of it. The 101st is a monstrosity of gerrymandering that disenfranchises voters and weakens representative democracy in upstate New York.

title: Three Found Guilty in N.C.A.A. Basketball Recruiting Scheme
description: A jury returned unanimous guilty verdicts against two former Adidas employees and an aspiring sports agent in Manhattan federal court Wednesday after more than two days deliberation, concluding that it constituted fraud for the defendants to funnel money to the families of college basketball recruits in exchange for the prospects commitment to teams sponsored by Adidas.

title: The Social Responsibility of Business
description: Back when I was in business school in the 1980s, I was taught  as were generations of aspiring entrepreneurs and executives  that the business of business is business. There is one and only one social responsibility of business, the economist Milton Friedman famously wrote in Capitalism and Freedom: to increase its profits. In an essay for this newspaper in 1970, Dr. Friedman went further, arguing that executives who claim that companies have responsibilities for providing employment, eliminating discrimination, avoiding pollution and whatever else may be the catchwords of the day are guilty of undermining the basis of a free society.

title: How Scientists Cracked the Climate Change Case
description: The latest report from the worlds climate scientists has made clear the size of the challenge if the world is to stay below the global warming limit hoped for in the Paris climate agreement. Unfortunately, with current trends we are likely to cross this threshold within the next two decades because we are already two-thirds of the way there.

title: Doctor, Vote Yourself
description: To the Editor:

title: Dianne Wiest Is a Boulder, but Not for Halloween
description: Dianne Wiest is reprising her role in Samuel Becketts Happy Days after starring in the play as Winnie at Theater for a New Audience last year. No, not on Broadway  in Madison Square Park. The Oscar-winning actress is performing selections from Becketts 1961 play at noon daily through Friday.

title: Registering to Vote at School
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Hostility Toward Iran: Its Time to Move On
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Arabia, China, Kit Kat: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trump and the Middle-Class Tax Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorism at Home: Bombs in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Stress May Impair Memory and Thinking Skills
description: People with high blood levels of cortisol, the stress hormone, may have poorer memory and thinking skills than those with lower levels.

title: Slumping Stock Market Enters Negative Territory for the Year
description: Another wave of selling hit the nearly decade-long bull market as investors worried that the ideal climate they have long enjoyed  a surging economy, low interest rates and fast-growing corporate profits  would soon be behind them.

title: South Carolina Police Officer, Ambushed by Gunman With 129 Firearms, Dies 3 Weeks After Attack
description: A second South Carolina police officer has died after being ambushed and shot earlier this month by a man with a stockpile of guns who opened fire on her and other officers as they tried to serve a warrant.

title: Overlooked No More: Rose Zar, a Holocaust Survivor Who Hid in Plain Sight
description: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, were adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

title: What 9 Art Buyers Wore to a Hamptons Art Fair
description: Jay-Z and Beyonc didnt show up this time. But the September Art Fair  an invitation-only open-air event held last month at a private golf resort in the Hamptons  still drew plenty of deep pockets. Along with works from blue-chip galleries including David Zwirner and Marlborough Contemporary, the second annual fair featured classic cars by Porsche, Ferrari and Maserati. It may have been after Labor Day, but these elite automobile fanatics and art aficionados werent afraid of wearing white.

title: Creepy Critters, and Landmark Lawsuits
description: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

title: F.D.A. Approves New Drug for Flu
description: The first new flu drug in 20 years won approval Wednesday from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Tesla Reports a Rare Quarterly Profit, Its Biggest Ever
description: Tesla on Wednesday reported its first quarterly profit in two years and its biggest ever. But for the electric-car maker and its unpredictable chief, the question is whether it can keep making money.

title: Debunking 5 Viral Images of the Migrant Caravan
description: A group of Honduran migrants traveling through Mexico toward the United States has attracted enormous amounts of attention in recent days, including a litany of false, misleading and unproven statements circulating on social media.

title: Osamu Shimomura, 90, Dies; Won Nobel for Finding a Glowing Protein
description: Osamu Shimomura, who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2008 for his discovery of a glowing jellyfish protein that is now ubiquitous in biomedical research, died on Friday in Nagasaki, Japan. He was 90.

title: Albert K. Smiley III, 74, Keeper of Mohonk Mountain House, Dies
description: Albert K. Smiley III, a hotelier who preserved Mohonk Mountain House in upstate New York as a 19th-century Victorian retreat that could have been inspired jointly by Rip Van Winkle and Charles Addams, while also nudging it gently into the next century, died on Oct. 16 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 74.

title: Andrew Gillum and Ron DeSantis Trade Attacks Over Corruption and Racism in Florida Debate
description: DAVIE, Fla.  Blistering verbal assaults overtook the race for Florida governor on Wednesday night, as rivals Andrew Gillum and Ron DeSantis presented voters with an onslaught of character insults in their final debate before the November election.

title: If U.S. Missiles Are Deployed, Putin Says, Europe at Risk of Counterstrike
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin warned on Wednesday that if the United States deploys new intermediate-range missiles in Europe after withdrawing from a nuclear treaty prohibiting these weapons, European nations will be at risk of a possible counterstrike.

title: The Danger of Running an Election on Fear
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: When Trump Phones Friends, the Chinese and the Russians Listen and Learn
description: WASHINGTON  When President Trump calls old friends on one of his iPhones to gossip, gripe or solicit their latest take on how he is doing, American intelligence reports indicate that Chinese spies are often listening  and putting to use invaluable insights into how to best work the president and affect administration policy, current and former American officials said.

title: Politics for Dessert: How Ben & Jerry Are Trying to Flip Congress
description: Behind the scenes with iconic ice cream makers Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, as they whip up new ice cream flavors in an effort to flip Congress.

title: Wells Fargo Suspends 2 Executives Amid Regulatory Review
description: Wells Fargo said it had suspended two senior executives as part of a continuing regulatory review of its sales practices, the latest blow to a bank that has spent years reeling from scandals.

title: FIFA Says Saudi State Funds Wont Pay for New Tournaments
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  FIFA moved to quell months of speculation that Saudi Arabia would invest billions in two new soccer tournaments by writing to its board to say that any possible deal will not include cash from state-owned investment funds.

title: She Helped Save Her Husbands Life With CPR, Then Gave Birth to Their Son
description: Ashley Goette of West St. Paul, Minn., is being compared to a superhero these days, and not just because shes a new mother. (Though her 22 hours of labor alone would qualify.) Its because in the span of four days, she not only gave birth to her first child, but also saved her husbands life.

title: Explosives, Midterms, Markets: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Cleveland Orchestra Fires Two Musicians for Sexual Misconduct
description: The Cleveland Orchestra, considered among the finest symphonic ensembles in the world, announced Wednesday that it had fired two prominent players for sexual misconduct and harassment.

title: Where a Closer Look at a Crime-Scene Photo Can Lead
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

title: Wanda Ferragamo, 96, Dies; Reigned Over Familys Luxury Goods Empire
description: Wanda Ferragamo, who stepped in to run her husband Salvatore Ferragamos shoemaking business after his death in 1960 and then oversaw its expansion into a global luxury goods brand, died on Friday in her hilltop villa near Florence. She was 96.

title: Review: Rowan Atkinson Returns in Johnny English Strikes Again
description: On the evidence, Rowan Atkinsons secret agent character, Johnny English, has grown slightly less bumbling over the years, and so has the series. Johnny English Strikes Again has a few more laughs and far fewer cringes (and stereotypes) than the two films that preceded it.

title: Microsofts Earnings Surge, as Cloud Bet Continues to Pay Off
description: SEATTLE  Apple has its cash cow, the iPhone, which has made it the worlds largest public company. Amazon transformed an array of industries, from logistics to the way consumers buy, to become the second largest. For Microsoft, which is gaining ground on Amazon, growth runs straight through the cloud.

title: Trumps New Pledge to Cut Taxes May Follow a Familiar Path
description: Ten months before President Trump began making promises of a 10 percent tax cut for the middle class, he signed a sweeping bill that included a 10 percent tax cut for the middle class.

title: World Series 2018: How the Red Sox Beat the Dodgers in Game 2
description: The Red Sox were the best team in baseball during the regular season and they are proving to be the best team in the postseason so far as well. After a 4-2 win over the Los Angeles Dodgers on Wednesday, Boston has a commanding two games to none lead in the 2018 World Series.

title: James Karen, Veteran Actor and Pathmark Man, Dies at 94
description: James Karen, an actor with some 200 television and film credits and one particularly memorable job as a supermarket pitchman that led many to call him simply the Pathmark Man, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 94.

title: Blackface Remarks by Megyn Kelly Lead to Rift With NBC
description: Megyn Kelly struggled on Wednesday to contain a growing crisis over her racially insensitive remarks during a Today show broadcast, statements that propelled longstanding tensions between the former Fox News anchor and her NBC News colleagues into public view.

title: Bernie Sanders: We Must Stop Helping Saudi Arabia in Yemen
description: The likely assassination of the Saudi critic and Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi underscores how urgent it has become for the United States to redefine our relationship with Saudi Arabia, and to show that the Saudis do not have a blank check to continue violating human rights.

title: Caetano Veloso: Dark Times Are Coming for My Country
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazil is not for beginners, Antonio Carlos Jobim used to say. Mr. Jobim, who wrote The Girl From Ipanema, was one of Brazils most important musicians, one whom we can thank for the fact that music lovers everywhere have to think twice before pigeonholing Brazilian pop as world music.

title: Rhetoric, Mobs and Terror
description: There is no way to consider the explosive devices sent to prominent Democrats and the CNN offices and not recall that Donald Trump himself has created a toxic environment by openly targeting many of these very people and entities in his overheated, overwrought rhetoric.

title: 2 Dead After Gunman Opens Fire at Kentucky Kroger, Police Say
description: A gunman fatally shot two people at a supermarket in Kentucky on Wednesday afternoon before an armed onlooker fired at him, prompting him to flee, the police said.

title: What Business Casual Really Means
description: Whether you are entering the work force for the first time, starting a new job or changing fields, choosing what to wear to work has never been more complicated. What constitutes business casual varies among companies, industries and parts of the world.

title: Dorcas Reilly, Creator of the Classic American Green-Bean Casserole, Dies at 92
description: It takes just minutes to whip up, and contains a mere six ingredients. But more than six decades after Dorcas B. Reilly invented the classic American dish of green-bean casserole when she worked in the Campbell Soup Company test kitchen, it remains a staple at Thanksgiving Day dinners across the country.

title: How the Migrant Caravan Became a Trump Election Strategy
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  The flier began circulating on social media in Honduras this month, showing a lone migrant sketched against a bright red backdrop.

title: Trumps Ignoring Our Real National Emergies
description: Its not about immigration. Its about bigotry.

title: Why Jamal Khashoggis Killing Has Resonated
description: The killing of the dissident writer Jamal Khashoggi inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul has resonated internationally in an unusually powerful way. In the weeks since he disappeared, his case has become a top story and a focal point for outrage.

title: Explosive Devices Add to Climate of Overheated Partisan Rancor
description: WASHINGTON  One suspicious package went to George Soros, the billionaire investor and liberal philanthropist who is a perpetual target of conservative conspiracy theories and smears  everything from being a former Nazi to the secret financier of the caravan of migrants making its way toward the United States.

title: Trump Gets Terrible
description: Terrible week. Donald Trump was on the road trying to rev up the country against a pitiful caravan of poor people struggling through Mexico. Meanwhile, there was a spate of bombing attempts directed at some of the presidents regular tirade targets, from Hillary Clinton to George Soros to CNN.

title: Rent Hike Hits Beloved Drama Book Shop
description: Over the past century, the Drama Book Shop, a legendary independent bookstore that has one of the largest selections of plays in the country, has survived a series of natural and man-made disasters: a fire that damaged a collection of signed first editions, floods, multiple break-ins and armed robberies (once, the thieves took the entire safe).

title: Looks Beneath the Surface
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Go on, tell me: How much do you dislike cross-referenced clues?

title: Catastrophic Super Typhoon Yutu Slams Into U.S. Commonwealth in the Pacific
description: Updated Oct. 25

title: What Does the Apparent Pipe Bomb Sent to CNN Reveal?
description: A suspicious device resembling a pipe bomb was sent to CNN and addressed to Barack Obamas ex-C.I.A. director John Brennan. Heres what we know about it.

title: Denmark Plans a Fence to Stop a Pig Disease. Will It Work?
description: TONDER, Denmark  Trying to halt the spread of a disease that can wipe out domestic pig populations, Denmark intends to build a fence along its border with Germany to keep out the pigs wild cousins. There are just a few wrinkles to the plan.

title: Menendez and Hugin Spar, With the Focus on Trump, in New Jersey Senate Debate
description: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and his Republican challenger, Bob Hugin, squared off in a debate Wednesday night that simmered with an undercurrent of contempt, but rarely erupted into the mudslinging that has defined the race as the candidates repeatedly focused their disagreements on President Trumps record.

title: A Mothers Voice Is the Most Effective Smoke Alarm
description: A mothers recorded voice will wake a child and get him out the room much faster than a standard smoke alarm, a randomized trial has found.

title: On Politics: Explosive Devices Sent to Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and CNN
description: Good Thursday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

title: Corrections: October 25, 2018
description: SPORTS

title: Pipe Bombs, Saudi Arabia, Vladimir Putin: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Quotation of the Day: How Rude Is Eating on the Subway? Transit Leader Draws the Line at Roast Chicken
description: I dont mind someone having a snack. A full-on subway meal or a roast chicken, leaving the bones all over the place, isnt acceptable.

title: World Series: David Price Leads Red Sox Past Dodgers in Game 2
description: BOSTON  No matter how often David Price came up short, no matter how frequently he looked in the mirror  or anywhere else  to search for answers to his playoff shortcomings, he kept getting back on the mound.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Heathers and Citizen Kane
description: A modern-day TV update of the 1989 film Heathers debuts on Paramount Network. And Citizen Kane is streaming on Filmstruck.

title: A Peoples Pig in China Could Be Headed to Upstate New York
description: BEIJING  Abby Rockefeller wants to bring the Peoples Pig of the Northeast back to the people. First, she has to bring it to upstate New York.

title: Word + Quiz: jounce
French Soccer Hunts for American Money
description: LONDON  French soccer is on a selling spree.

title: U.S. Admission of North Korean Defectors Has Slowed to a Trickle
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Before sunrise each day, Holly Hwang nestles her little girl into a carrier and bikes her to a day care center. It is a 10-mile slog, sometimes through rain or snow, before she reaches the warehouse where she earns $9.52 an hour operating a forklift. After clocking out, she rides back another 10 miles to pick up her 4-year-old and head home.

title: The Harmonie Club Joins the 21st Century
description: The new general manager of the Harmonie Club, Davina Weinstein, stood in its gleaming marble lobby on an early October evening and mingled with members who congratulated her on landing the job.

title: Candy Around the World
description: What are your favorite candies? Why? What candies do you dislike? What types did you like best as a child? Have your candy tastes changed over the years? Do you know the history or national origin of any of your favorites?

title: Stocks Climb, Recovering From a Decline That Wiped Out 2018s Gains
description: Stocks rebounded on Thursday as strong earnings from major tech companies seemed to ease some of the worries driving a recent wave of selling that had wiped out the markets gains for the year.

title: Cathay Pacific Data Breach Exposes 9.4 Million Passengers
description: Cathay Pacific, the Hong Kong-based international airline, acknowledged on Wednesday that its computer system had been compromised at least seven months ago, exposing the personal data and travel histories of as many as 9.4 million people.

title: Learning With: Pipe Bombs Sent to Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and CNN Offices
description: Before reading the article:

title: Frankenstein at 200
description: At movie awards ceremonies, most winners thank their stars, their agents, their significant others. Guillermo del Toro, during his victory lap earlier this year for The Shape of Water, thanked a teenager who had been dead for more than 150 years.

title: We Feel a Kinship With the Creature
description: Just five years after the 1818 publication of Mary Shelleys Frankenstein; or The Modern Prometheus, the novel had been already adapted for the stage, and artists in all media have continued to reanimate the tale ever since.

title: Its Alive! Well, the Puppeteers Are
description: CHICAGO  In Mary Shelleys Frankenstein, creation is a work of breathless horror. In a rehearsal room here on a recent Saturday, creation was also breathless and very cold. (A fan had broken; the heating had quit.) Scarf-clad actors shivered as they raced around the stage, dodging extension cords, manipulating four overhead projectors. On a small table at the center, a monster slouched, waiting to be born.

title: The Nuts and Bolts of Frankensteins Movie Monsters
description: From bolted brutes to stitched-up superstars, Frankensteins monster has taken on many forms in its more than a century of depictions on the big screen. One look caught on more than many others. But filmmakers have displayed a variety of visions in bringing this creature to life, and not just in the horror genre. The monster has wobbled its way through comedy, exploitation and family-friendly animation, too, as this selection of portrayals shows.

title: Barbara Kingsolver: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of the novel Unsheltered loves fiction that educates me on the sly, especially about something I didnt realize I wanted to know. Im open to any kind of arcana.

title: Seven Hotels Ready to Help You Get Fit by New Years
description: Theres still time this year to meet your New Years resolution that wellness should be a priority in your life. Several hotels around the United States are offering an array of new incentives to reach your goal with health-focused amenities that are included in the cost of your stay.

title: Poem: VI. Penelopes Lament
description: The joy that meets the arrival of a new book by Barbara Hamby is comparable to standing before the many-chambered facade of an Advent calendar: Each page opens onto a new wonder. Unfortunately, most of the buoyant monologues in Bird Odyssey are too long to reprint in this column; fortunately, however, the final section of the poem The Odyssey in Six Sonnets satisfies space limitations while delivering on its titular boast. Bawdy and irreverent, with a technically superb mix of high and low diction: Heres Penelopes take on the story we thought we knew. Selected by Rita Dove

title: How I Discovered This Thing Called Music
description: I didnt listen to music until I was 27 years old. And even then, it wasnt entirely by choice. It was suggested to me by one doctor and several Reddit users.

title: Are You Watching the World Series?
description: It has been over a century since the Dodgers faced the Red Sox in a World Series. Did you watch Game 1 on Tuesday night? Will you be watching the rest of the series?

title: How End Mass Incarceration Became a Slogan for D.A. Candidates
description: DALLAS  The Dallas County district attorney, Faith Johnson, often reminds voters that she recently won a rare murder conviction against a white police officer who shot into a car full of teenagers, killing a black 15-year-old boy.

title: Bruno Latour, the Post-Truth Philosopher, Mounts a Defense of Science
description: In the summer of 1996, during an international anthropology conference in southeastern Brazil, Bruno Latour, Frances most famous and misunderstood philosopher, was approached by an anxious-looking developmental psychologist. The psychologist had a delicate question, and for this reason he requested that Latour meet him in a secluded spot  beside a lake at the Swiss-style resort where they were staying. Removing from his pocket a piece of paper on which hed scribbled some notes, the psychologist hesitated before asking, Do you believe in reality?

title: Can There Really Be Two Moms?
description: No, Mama Steph, go away. I want Mama Sabby to read to me! These words from my 3-year-old daughter, Marty, level me like the most withering insult. Lately, her extreme favoritism for my spouse, Sabrina, has reached new heights. She even gets mad if I peck Sabrina on the cheek or place my arm around her seat as she drives.

title: Apple Newss Radical Approach: Humans Over Machines
description: Many of Apples employees moved into a glistening new $5 billion glass headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., this year. A mile west, at Apples old campus on 1 Infinite Loop, a project antithetical to Silicon Valleys ethos is now underway.

title: Bringing Africa to the World
description: WASHINGTON  Gus Casely-Hayford, of London, started as the director of the Smithsonians National Museum of African Art in February. He talks about his passion for sharing the astonishing breadth of his parents continent, the need to go global and digital, and his desire to renovate. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: 36 Hours in Singapore
description: Singapores main island is sometimes described as diamond-shaped  fitting, perhaps, since the sparkling city, which had a starring role in the movie Crazy Rich Asians, is known for its materialistic pursuits. But look past Singapores shiny veneer and youll find a compression of Chinese, Indian, Malay and other heritages reaching back far beyond the city states half-century history as an independent nation. And thanks to the superb street food and efficient public transit, you dont have to be crazy rich to enjoy this cinematic city, which is now more accessible than ever with Singapore Airlines new nonstop service from Newark.

title: Who Actually Listens to Halloween Music?
description: The Christmas music obsessive is a familiar specimen. Encouraged by premature holiday displays in drugstores and overeager TV commercials, this invasive species begins to play songs like Santa Baby and All I Want for Christmas Is You months before the holiday arrives.

title: Dispatches From a Ruined Paradise
description: Robert Adamss succinct preface to his 2010 book of photographs What Can We Believe Where? begins with uplift: In common with many photographers, he writes, I began making pictures because I wanted to record what supports hope: the untranslatable mystery and beauty of the world. Adamss aim was true. Look at one of his photographs and youll see a record of mystery and beauty. The photographic elements are simple. Bright sunlight, generally; crisp shadow; the occasional moody nocturne. We feel as if we are being taught to see with a visual primer. Better yet, turn the pages of one of his books (he has made more than 50) or walk around an exhibition of his work, inhabiting the flow of his decisions. You are likely to feel your breath getting calmer and your senses quietened.

title: Rooftop Gardens Are Turning the Urban Shopping Scene Green
description: PARIS  Its a swift ride by elevator from Galeries Lafayettes perfume section to the grand department stores 10th-floor luxury farm with its signature scent of sage, rosemary and compost.

title: In Auction World, Edward Dolman Aims to Make Phillips a Player
description: Dont feel sorry for Edward Dolman.

title: Three Campaign Ads That Are Putting Climate Change on the Agenda
description: Conventional political wisdom says you dont talk about climate change on the campaign trail.

title: Alex de Minaur, at 19, Is Still Learning
description: Alex de Minaur, 19, of Australia is the second youngest in the ATPs top 100. Since turning pro in 2015, he has quickly established himself as a player with intense focus and fight. This month he unseated Nick Kyrgios as Australias top tennis player. He will play at the Paris Masters, which starts on Friday. This conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: When Art Comes Along for the Ride
description: As buses rumble down a corridor in the new Salesforce Transit Center (which recently has been closed after the discovery of structural cracks) they trigger 247 water jets to spout in Bus Jet Fountain by the San Francisco artist Ned Kahn. The 1,000-foot-long aquatic installation, on the rooftop of the hub, entices pedestrians above to trace commuters progress (or lack thereof) in splashy real time.

title: Novak Djokovic Can Regain the No. 1 Ranking in Paris
description: Ranked No. 22 in June, Novak Djokovic has an excellent chance to be back at No. 1 by November.

title: 4 Women Try to Unseat House Republicans in N.Y.; Donors and Celebrities Take Notice
description: In most any other election year, the four female Democratic candidates in New York trying to unseat House Republicans would draw little more than curiosity.

title: New Attention for Figures in the Background
description: In any survey class of Western art, douard Manets 1863 painting Olympia invariably comes up on the screen. Professors typically discuss how the naked white prostitute displayed starkly across her bed meets our gaze confrontationally, rejecting the age-old representation of the demure courtesan and presaging the birth of modernism.

title: In-Match Tennis Coaching Is Hiding in Plain Sight
description: Brad Stine is a remarkable, deeply experienced coach and a law-abiding man in general. But like many in professional tennis, he has regularly broken the rules by coaching during matches.

title: A Broadway Actor Has a Heart-to-Heart About Life and Laundry
description: Last summer, Chase Ramsey  an actor known to tourists as the California Dream Eater, eating his way through the Golden State  landed a role in The Book of Mormon on Broadway.

title: How Screwed Up Is American Democracy?
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

title: Ballot Applications in Georgia, and Senate and House Latest: 12 Days to Go
description: Welcome to The Tip Sheet, a daily political analysis of the 2018 elections, based on interviews with Republican and Democratic officials, pollsters, strategists and voters.

title: Maya Lin Captures the Hudsons Beauty and Power
description: When Miwako Tezuka was invited to guest curate an exhibition at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, N.Y., two thoughts sprang into her mind.

title: A Gallery by Any Other Name, Size and Shape?
description: Either you dig in, invest and expand or, in essence, you dont grow.

title: A Black Senate Candidate Stumps in Mississippi, but His Party Holds Him Back
description: INDIANOLA, Miss.  When Mike Espy, a young black lawyer from a prominent local family, first campaigned for Congress in this tidy Delta town 30 years ago, many white voters refused to shake his hand. The onetime home of both B. B. King and the White Citizens Council, Indianola embodied the gulf that has divided Mississippi for centuries.

title: A Baseball Bat Dies, and Chopsticks Are Born
description: TOKYO  The bats the Red Sox and the Dodgers break during the World Series are likely to be sold at team stores or by memorabilia companies, donated to charity, given away or even repurposed as wooden handles for bottle openers.

title: What Being Transgender Looks Like, According to Stock Photography
description: Transgender people are appearing more often in advertisements and mass media. But when they do, its very often in stock photos that show them standing against a blank wall, or else they are hardly seen at all. The most used stock photos are close-ups of their hands holding the symbol for transgender pride, without their faces or other defining features visible.

title: How Short Can the Intervals in Interval Training Get?
description: The appeal of high-intensity interval training is obvious: shorter workouts whose health benefits, according to studies in recent years, are nonetheless as effective as much longer sessions of endurance training. Less obvious is just how short the intervals can get  and how this form of training really impacts the body at a cellular level. A new study in The Journal of Physiology might be a step toward settling both questions.

title: Stephen Colbert Criticizes Trumps Response to Attempted Bombings
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If youre interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

title: Pakistan Tries a New Way to Pay for a Dam: Crowdsourcing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pav Akhtar is not one to fall for TV donation ads. In fact, he says, he and his siblings jokingly chide their mother for watching them on Pakistani satellite channels at their home in Lancashire, England.

title: Pipe Bombs, Stock Market, Megyn Kelly: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: A Gender Swap Makes Sondheims Company Soar
description: LONDON  At last, Company has a human pulse and a proper dramatic core. And for that to happen, it took a woman.

title: Alex Honnold, a Soul Freed in Free Solo
description: In 1923, the mountaineer George Mallory gave an interview to The New York Times in which he famously explained why he was determined to summit Mount Everest. Because its there. He died in the attempt the following year. Alex Honnold, who last year became the first person to climb Yosemites El Capitan alone and without a rope, seems to have a different explanation for why he climbs. Because Im here.

title: How 1994 Gave Us Todays Politics
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: New York Today: What We Know About the Mail Bombs
description: Updated, 9:40 a.m.

title: The Gender War, 2018 Edition
description: On Oct. 11, when Victoria Bissell Browns husband Jim made a dismissive remark, I just blew and ranted, she told me in a phone interview. He suddenly became all men.

title: Playing the Long Game for the Supreme Court
description: It was 31 years ago this week, on Oct. 23, 1987, that the Senate rejected the Supreme Court nomination of Robert H. Bork. Thirty-one years and a world ago: eight senators crossed party lines, with six Republicans joining 52 Democrats in voting against confirmation, while two Democrats joined 40 Republicans in supporting President Ronald Reagans nominee, one of the countrys best known and most outspoken conservative intellectuals. It was the biggest margin of defeat for any Supreme Court nominee in history.

title: DealBook Briefing: This Years Stock Gains Are Wiped Out
description: Good Thursday. Want this by email? Sign up here.

title: Win No. 2 for a Red Sox Team Looking Like the Inevitable Champion
description: BOSTON  The Boston Red Sox earned 108 victories in the regular season, and it turns out they hadnt even played their best. Now they have, and as the World Series shifts to Dodger Stadium for Game 3 on Friday, a sense of inevitability moves with it.

title: China Mocks Report It Tapped Trumps iPhone (and Plugs Its Own Competitor)
description: BEIJING  China on Thursday ridiculed but did not exactly deny an article in The New York Times detailing how Chinese intelligence agents eavesdropped on cellphone conversations President Trump had with friends in hopes of gaining insights into the administrations policies.

title: Review: In 1985, a Young Man Hides a Plague From His Family
description: The AIDS crisis, which will remain a global crisis until a definitive cure for the disease is found, is no longer at the foreground of our culture. The film 1985 is a moving cinematic sketch of a HIV-infected man living through the height of the plague.

title: Review: In London Fields, Sex, Apocalypse and Writers Block
description: London Fields, directed by Matthew Cullen and adapted from Martin Amiss 1989 novel, is, quite simply, horrendous  a trashy, tortured misfire from beginning to end.

title: Review: In Shirkers, Stolen Footage and Dashed Dreams
description: Shirkers is the director Sandi Tans first feature  the first, at least, that anyone has been allowed to see. Back in 1992, as a rebellious 19-year-old in Singapore, she wrote and starred in a subversive road movie about a female assassin, enlisting her closest friends, Jasmine Ng and Sophie Siddique, to help with editing and production. The completed project, captured on 70 canisters of donated 16-millimeter film, was then relinquished to its director: a slippery, middle-aged American film teacher named Georges Cardona. They never saw him again.

title: Review: In Vaya, Three Travelers Find Danger in Johannesburg
description: Probing the space between innocence and experience, the director Akin Omotosos fourth feature, Vaya, is a story of narrow escapes and even narrower choices.

title: Review: Foreign Land Sees a Better Past Than Future for the Middle East
description: Im angry at myself for having children, Ghassan Abbas, an Israeli-born Arab, says near the end of Foreign Land. Where did I bring them to? What kind of world?

title: Review: Viper Club Looks Behind the Scenes of a Press Kidnapping
description: Viper Club begins as a movie about a mother trying to rescue her son  a journalist kidnapped while reporting from Syria  and gradually reveals that its as much a character study as a procedural. Although its dedicated, in part, to reporters like James Foley and Steven J. Sotloff, who were held captive and killed by the Islamic State, to call it an issue movie would be to shortchange it.

title: Review: In Dont Go, Will a Dads Dreams Change Reality?
description: As an actor, Stephen Dorff possesses an elusive, languorous quality that can make even a run-of-the-mill popcorn flick light up with mystery. In the otherwise middling thriller Dont Go, Dorff is strikingly enigmatic in his role as Ben, an acclaimed writer remaking his life as a schoolteacher in Ireland with his wife, Hazel (Melissa George), after the sudden death of their young daughter. While Hazel establishes roots, starting a new hotel business, Ben is drawn away from reality by the vivid hold of his dreams.

title: Review: In Boosting Blockchain, Trust Machine Chains Itself In
description: A hodgepodge of boosterish arguments for blockchain technology, Trust Machine: The Story of Blockchain, directed by Alex Winter (Bill of Bill & Ted fame), is not always a model of clarity, but it does a decent job of explaining the basic concept. Mark Jeffrey, an entrepreneur looking to blockchain for his start-up, describes the technology as a kind of shared, decentralized ledger: A record of all the transactions, and its constructed in such a way that cheating is not possible.

title: Review: Hunter Killer Explores the Depths of Geopolitics
description: In Hunter Killer, ordinary alliances are suddenly upended and the United States Navy must do whatever it can to protect the interests of the Russian president. No, its not a documentary; its a submarine movie.

title: Review: Sniffing Out Guilt in a Strangely Engaging Border
description: Tina works security at a Swedish port. As passengers walk up a long corridor toward the terminal, she stands and looks at them. And she sniffs. Sometimes her lip curls, revealing stubby, yellow teeth. Her jutting brow ridge furrows a bit. If something agitates her, she growls. Quietly, as if trying to suppress it.

title: Pipe Bombs Investigation Turns Toward Florida as More Trump Critics Are Targeted
description: [Latest: two more devices were intercepted, one addressed to Senator Cory Booker and the other to James R. Clapper Jr., the former senior intelligence official.]

title: Reader Idea | College Students and Disabled Adults Create Spooky Found Poetry Together
description: Here is a special Halloween-appropriate edition of our Great Ideas from Readers series. It tells the story of what happened when a college class and a program for adults with intellectual disabilities came together to experiment with poetry.

title: East Island, Remote Hawaiian Sliver of Sand, Is Largely Wiped Out by a Hurricane
description: First, the island was there. Then, it was mostly gone.

title: Saudi Arabia, in Reversal, Suggests Khashoggis Killing Was Premeditated
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabias public prosecutor acknowledged for the first time on Thursday that the killing of the dissident columnist Jamal Khashoggi appeared to have been premeditated  yet another shift in the kingdoms account of his disappearance in Turkey.

title: Twitter Posts Another Profit as User Numbers Drop
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitter is still turning a profit  but it is continuing to have trouble holding on to its users.

title: A National Anti-Voting Movement
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: U.S. Hunter Kills Beautiful Goat. Now Scotland Is Scrutinizing Its Laws.
description: LONDON  The Scottish government said it was reviewing its animal culling laws after a photograph of an American hunter posing with the carcass of a black-faced goat with magnificent horns during a hunting trip to Scotland set off a furor on social media this past week.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, Lenox Hill, and Gramercy Park.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom in Ossining, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Byram, N.J.

title: San Diegos Power Move: City Takes on Utility Over Green Energy
description: Good morning.

title: On the Market in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Megyn Kellys Blackface Remarks Leave Her Future at NBC in Doubt
description: On the Tuesday episode of her show, Megyn Kelly made remarks on blackface Halloween costumes that caused a backlash. On Wednesday, she looked into the camera and apologized. On Thursday, she did not go to work, and a rerun of Megyn Kelly Today replaced the live broadcast of her show.

title: Yes, Houses Are Bigger in Texas
description: Over the past few decades, American homes have been getting larger. The median size of a new single-family house grew from 1,525 square feet in 1973 to a peak of 2,488 square feet in 2015, according to census data. As of the second quarter of 2018, that figure had leveled off to 2,412 square feet  hardly a tiny house.

title: Dominant Doubles Tennis Player Adjusts to the Spotlight
description: Few tennis players have been as dominant in their events this year as Demi Schuurs, but she nearly missed the WTA Finals.

title: There Is a Silver Lining for Losers of Amazons HQ2 Competition
description: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines  and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

title: Hollywoods Forgotten Heroes: Female War Correspondents
description: The voice has stayed with Rosamund Pike. For the new movie A Private War, the British actress transformed her posh, rounded speech into a distinctive American rasp, to play Marie Colvin, the Long Island-raised, London-based journalist who was killed in Syria in 2012. On tough occasions, Pike still imagines using her tone: It suggests a woman who gets things done.

title: Film Club: Vic Invades
description: Note to teachers: This weeks film includes footage of UrbExing, or urban exploration, which often includes illicit and dangerous activities. Please preview before sharing the film with students to make sure it is appropriate for your class.

title: Tech Earnings Provide a Breather From the Selling
description: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines  and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

title: Review: Monrovia, Indiana Is a Sharp, Lyrical Look at Small-Town America
description: Walt Whitman wrote that the United States themselves are essentially the greatest poem, and in a Whitmanian temper I would argue that Frederick Wiseman is the greatest American poet.

title: University Backed by George Soros Prepares to Leave Budapest Under Duress
description: BUDAPEST  In 1989, as the Soviet Union crumbled and countries across Eastern and Central Europe emerged from decades of political oppression, a group of intellectuals led by the Hungarian-born philanthropist George Soros proposed a university that would help in the transition to democracy from dictatorship.

title: China Locks Up Ethnic Minorities in Camps. It Says So Itself.
description: NOTTINGHAM, England  Citizens, please remain calm and relax, no one in the re-education camps will starve, be left in the cold, be punished or be forced to work. With these words, an official from Chinas Communist Youth League tried to reassure relatives and friends of members of predominantly Muslim ethnic minorities who had been taken to internment centers. The detainees were infected by an ideological illness, the official said, and the camps would cleanse the virus from their brain.

title: Trump, Partisan and Pugilist, Abandons Calls for Unity After Bomb Scares
description: WASHINGTON  In moments of national crisis, presidents typically reach for unifying themes, as Bill Clinton did after the Oklahoma City bombing and George W. Bush did with the bullhorn on the wrecked fire truck after 9/11. President Trump on Thursday chose confrontation over conciliation.

title: Whats All This About Journaling?
description: It was my ex-husband who got me journaling again. Our marriage was falling apart, and, on the advice of his friend, he had started to do morning pages, a daily journaling practice from the seminal self-help book The Artists Way.

title: This Weeks Mail Bombs Are No Surprise
description: What role does inflammatory rhetoric play in inciting acts of terrorism and violence? This question has been thrust into the headlines after explosive devices were sent to former President Barack Obama, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the New York offices of CNN, the Westchester home of George Soros and at least five other locations, all frequent targets of vitriolic right-wing criticism.

title: French Spider-Man, Alain Robert, Is Charged for London Tower Climb
description: LONDON  A French extreme free climber who calls himself Spider-Man and who has become famous for scaling buildings around the world climbed Heron Tower, the tallest building in London Citys square mile, on Thursday afternoon.

title: Revoking Parole for Marijuana Use Makes No Sense
description: Last week, the New York State Assembly held its first hearing on the historic possibility of legalizing marijuana for recreational use in New York. As a former New York City probation commissioner, I testified on the behalf of four other former probation commissioners for the city.

title: The Beauty of Saumur Champigny, Not Always Appreciated
description: Certain types of wine seem incapable of winning popular acceptance.

title: Once Lowly, Carignan Finds Favor in California
description: For one of the most widely grown red grapes in the world, carignan is perhaps among the least known and most misunderstood.

title: Why Has the Stock Market Been Dropping? The Expansion Heads Toward a New Phase
description: The stock market drop in October has been unsettling for anyone with a portfolio, particularly after a 3 percent plunge Wednesday that wiped out the years gains. Could this be the beginning of a larger crash, or a recession?

title: European Parliament Approves Ban on Single-Use Plastics
description: LONDON  The European Parliament has overwhelmingly approved a ban on single-use plastics such as straws, plates, cutlery and cotton-swab sticks in Europe by 2021, joining a global shift as environmentalists emphasize the urgency of halting the use of materials that are detrimental to the planet.

title: The Week in Good News: London Jazz, Lavender for Anxiety, Candy
description: Sometimes it seems as if were living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isnt all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart. Want to get The Week in Good News by email? Sign up here.

title: AI Art at Christies Sells for $432,500
description: Last Friday, a portrait produced by artificial intelligence was hanging at Christies New York opposite an Andy Warhol print and beside a bronze work by Roy Lichtenstein. On Thursday, it sold for well over double the price realized by both those pieces combined.

title: Altria to Stop Selling Some E-Cigarette Brands That Appeal to Youths
description: WASHINGTON  Under pressure to curb vaping among young people, the tobacco giant Altria announced on Thursday that it would discontinue most of its flavored e-cigarettes and stop selling some brands altogether.

title: Cant You Be a Little Nicer, for the Kids?
description: My husband and I have been separated for nine months; our divorce will be final soon. We share joint custody of our two children. The problem: Whenever were together, usually at events where the kids are also present (like parent-teacher meetings or visiting day at camp), he wont speak to me or even make eye contact with me. He will only communicate with me by text. Its embarrassing for me to have him act this way in front of others. Im also worried that his behavior creates stress for our children, who are already stressed about the divorce. Any advice?

title: Ellisons Troubles in Minnesota Create Unexpected Opening for His Opponent
description: ST. PAUL  Doug Wardlow was a little-known former state representative 18 months ago when he announced what appeared to be a long-shot candidacy to be Minnesotas next attorney general.

title: A Sculpture in Kosovo That Tracks a Countrys Struggle
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  A decade ago, Fisnik Ismaili designed a sculpture to celebrate Kosovos declaration of independence from Serbia: It was a word, Newborn, in 10-foot letters, painted a garish yellow. He did not have the cash to pay the metalworkers who built it, so he left his car and house keys as a deposit.

title: Ethiopia Appoints Its First Female President
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  A week after Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia filled half of his new cabinet with women in a radical overhaul, the countrys Parliament took another step toward gender parity on Thursday by appointing the countrys first female president.

title: Trump Considers Closing Southern Border to Migrants
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump is considering taking executive action to bar migrants, including asylum seekers, from entering the country at the southern border, according to people familiar with the plan. The effort would be the starkest indication yet of Mr. Trumps election-season push to play to his anti-immigrant base as his party fights to keep control of Congress.

title: Japanese Food on Three Levels
description: Kisum offers a number of experiences, including a $195 omakase at its top-floor chefs table.

title: Review: In The Dark, a Traumatized Teenager Becomes a Zombie
description: The horror film The Dark begins queasily, following a man, Josef (Karl Markovics), who has absconded with a blind, bound teenage boy to a cabin deep in a shadowy wood known as Devils Den. Josef has monstrous intentions, but he is no match for the forests demons.

title: Review: Kisum in Melbourne, Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  There is a certain sector of Australian dining that relies on trickle-down reputation  the idea that the prowess of one chef or flagship restaurant confers immediate status on every other related project. But rarely have I seen this concept contained within one restaurant, in one building.

title: How Google Protected Andy Rubin, the Father of Android
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google gave Andy Rubin, the creator of Android mobile software, a heros farewell when he left the company in October 2014.

title: Rights Prize Goes to Oleg Sentsov, a Russian Prisoner, in a Rebuke to Putin
description: MOSCOW  The European Parliament on Thursday awarded a prestigious human rights prize to a Ukrainian prisoner serving a 20-year term in a penal colony in Siberia, drawing renewed attention to political detainees in the far-flung prison system once known as the gulag.

title: Aftermath of Typhoon Yutu in Saipan
